instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Arrived not powering on with liquid damage. Before replacing components it was drawing 20V. After replacing <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> and U650 it somehow went down to  5V.

PP3V42 is present at 3.42V What can cause it to go from 20V to 5V?? What should be checked next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Probably corrosion under some BGA chips; could be <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, or <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>.
Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, voltage and diode mode.
Do you get <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

"U650"
???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Where else did you note liquid on the board?
Try to reflow USB-C input area.
You may need to reball <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: only areas were <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> area along with audio section. CD3215s were reflowed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Looks like <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> area reacted to the heat when you've changed the chips.
Try reballing both of them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> that had liquid spill and its now solved.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
not solved. After ultrasonic board only drawing 20v at 0.01a

noticed small bridge on <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR>. Fixed bridge powered again then smoked in area. Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR> and booted successfully once. Now stuck at 0.01a again and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted 0.001 diode mode.

Any way to find short without injecting voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Bad news :(.

"<TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR>"
Do you mean <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR>?
I cannot find any <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR> in schematic...

Check ohm mode at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and all big coils, especially CPU ones.
Any has the same value as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Don't forget L7690, as you had problem there.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7684</RESISTOR>/85/86 and <CAPACITOR>C7689</CAPACITOR> are good, as traces too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
yes, I meant <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR>

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ohm value the same as all the big coils around 1.2

Replaced <RESISTOR>R7686</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7689</CAPACITOR> but still no change. The <RESISTOR>R7684</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7685</RESISTOR> measured normal

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> caused <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short. Replaced and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> back to 13V but board only drawing 0.04 and 0.05 amps.

What to check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Overvoltage on L7690 could be letal damage.
Check basic signals for power on sequence.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> does not appear on board view

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is shorted. Should voltage be injected to find short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Which is the exact ohm value to ground?
First remove <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>, one by one; and check value each time.
If still low value, then you can inject, if is the case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
1.6 ohm is really problem now.
You can start injecting with 2V, no more than 4V in any case.
